PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Prime Minister's rhetoric consistently claims that Australia is well placed to cope with zero tariffs by 2010. Is it a fact that Australia's growth rate is around four to five per cent, when Taiwan, Korea, Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia are running at between six and nine per cent? Is it a fact that Australia has one of the lowest, if not the lowest, level of exports as a percentage of output in the region? Is it a fact that Australia's real interest rate is about the highest in the region, with the exception of Indonesia? Is it also a fact that we have the highest unemployment rate—nine per cent, compared with rates of three per cent or less for many of the Asian economies which are members of APEC? Why is it that Australia performs so poorly when compared with its Asian neighbours? Why do we keep running into current account problems? Why can Australia not sell more of its GDP abroad, instead of consuming itself? Is it not about time we had some real micro-economic reform in this country, if we want to avoid being taken to the cleaners by APEC? (Time expired)

—One hears occasions when people fundamentally and comprehensively miss the point, but rarely so spectacularly as on this occasion with Senator Alston. The truth of the matter is that Australia is the second biggest developed economy in the whole of the East Asian-Oceania region. Our growth is proceeding against a base which is very much larger than that of any other developed economy in the region, except Japan's. Our economy, in GDP terms, has been, until very recently, equivalent to the six ASEAN economies all put together. I think it is now equivalent to about five of them, because they have been growing so fast. We have an environment where the Australian economy is extraordinarily competitive, extraordinarily resilient and extraordinarily capable of doing everything we want it to be able to do to take advantage of this brilliant new opportunity that has opened up for us as a result of the APEC conference.

PARA.TAB: As Senator McMullan was saying on radio, I think this morning, it is really just a matter of what cast of mind we bring to these sorts of situations. Either we bring the pessimistic, dog-in-the-manger, miserable, mean-spirited cast of mind that Senator Alston so admirably represents in this place and say, `Australia can't do it. Australia is bound to be lagging behind whatever action is going on elsewhere,' or we say, `This is a phenomenal opportunity that has opened up for us to get much greater penetration and access into these markets around the region than we have ever previously been able to do.' We can do so from a base of micro-economic reform; we can do so from a base of trade liberalisation of a unilateral kind; and we can do so from the base of tariffs and quotas and so on which make us already very close to meeting these objectives that are being mapped in the APEC process.

We will have an average effective rate of assistance down to 2.9 per cent by the year 2000. That will be in spectacular contrast to most of our regional neighbours. We will have automotive down to 15 per cent and we will have TCF down to 25 per cent by the year 2000, which will be in spectacular contrast to the sorts of rates of 100, 150 and 200 per cent plus which are prevailing still very widely in the region.

We are already competitive in terms of our capacity to penetrate those markets even against barriers of that size. And with this particular process at work and operating to create a whole new environment in the region of many many more points of accessibility elsewhere, the opportunities for us and what this represents for us represent nothing but good value. It is an outstanding opportunity to build on the strengths that we have.

We have an economy with a growth rate that is as high as Senator Alston says, which puts us in spectacular contrast to the rest of the developed world, and against the base on which that growth is building it puts us in very good company indeed in the region. We have got inflation that is still absolutely rock solidly under control. We have got investment growing phenomenally strongly; new assets increased 10.5 per cent in the June quarter; and investment in new plant and equipment increased 13.4 per cent in that quarter. We have got an economy that is perfectly poised and perfectly shaped to take advantage of this new opportunity.

What we need to be doing is instilling a sense of confidence and optimism in those entrepreneurs who are now going to get out there and take advantage of these opportunities, not just sitting around talking the economy down, as Senator Alston is so spectacularly wont to do, and has done again on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I notice that the minister did not deny any of those propositions which demonstrate beyond doubt that Australia is very poorly placed relative to its neighbours and is prepared to rely on blind optimism. We heard the minister talk about a base of micro-economic reform. When are we going to have some real micro-economic reform in this country? The minister talks about a `rock solid' base of inflation being under control. Why is the government rolling over in front of Bill Kelty? Why is the government letting him decide that Australia can afford 15 per cent wage increases across the board? Why does the government not do something tough about the economy if it is so serious and hopeful about what is going to happen in the future?

—`Why don't you do something tough?', he says. `Why don't you do something tough like slashing the budget?', when every time he opens his mouth in terms of expenditure it is in order to suggest that we ought to be spending more on something else. `Why don't you act tough on wages policy?' those opposite say, when they were responsible when they were last in government for the kind of inattention and irresponsibility to both micro-economic reform and industrial relations reform that created the conditions that drove this country onto the rocks over and over again in those past decades.

PARA.TAB: As to the point about wages policy, of course it is not surprising in times of economic activity like this that significant wage increases would be sought across enterprises in various industries. What is absolutely crucial is that those wage improvements are associated with productivity improvements at the enterprise level and are tailored to the need of individual enterprises. And that is exactly what Bill Kelty said and what is reported in the paper this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what Kelty said.

—You do not read the headlines; you read what people say. What he said was that if they are offset by productivity increases or taken in the form of profit sharing schemes, that is the way to go—and of course it is. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the current trial of the clean food marketing campaign being undertaken in Taiwan. Can the minister inform the Senate whether this campaign has had any impact on the attitude of Taiwanese consumers to Australian food?

—This is an extremely appropriate question after the tirade we just heard from Senator Alston, because it is a small but useful indication as to just what benefits do await Australia from the APEC success. The clean food marketing campaign has been designed specifically to market and promote Australia's food exports to Taiwan on the basis of Australia's comparatively clean environment—a recognised competitive advantage, Senator Alston, that our country has.

PARA.TAB: The marketing activities undertaken over a period of five months to September 1994 include four periods of television advertising, seven weeks of supermarket promotions, and involvement in a number of trade fairs. There are 19 Australian companies which are licensees to the program, ranging from major players such as Goodman Fielder, statutory marketing bodies, including the Australian Dairy Corporation, to relatively small companies such as Hartz mineral water from Tasmania. I am pleased to advise the Senate that Arnotts Ltd has just confirmed that it will join the campaign and will begin marketing its products in Taiwan almost immediately.

The Clean Food Marketing Australia company commissioned a special report comparing results from consumer surveys conducted at the beginning and the end of the trial period. This campaign has been running for only a relatively short period of time but the findings are extremely encouraging.

They include the fact that the spontaneous awareness of Australia as a source of imported food products increased from 21 per cent to 41 per cent. One in three Taiwanese now considers Australia a supplier of high quality foods—a 50 per cent increase in that response. Over half of the Taiwanese consumers polled now perceive Australia as a clean environment. The incidence of Taiwanese who are consciously purchasing Australian imported products increased significantly, from 54 per cent to 81 per cent, representing a major increase in clear intention to buy Australian food products.

These survey results will form one part of a comprehensive evaluation of the Taiwan trial, which will also analyse the views of the licensees, local distributors and key stakeholders, including the government. The Agrifood Council, which initiated this clean food campaign and which is co-chaired by Senator Cook and me, will meet in Canberra tomorrow to, among other things, consider the draft evaluation report and determine a position on whether this campaign should be extended into other Asian markets.The Agrifood Council will also be finalising a document for public release which takes stock of the council's activities over the last two years and identifies core priorities to be pursued by the council into the future.

As I said before, this week's historic decision by APEC leaders in which Australia, and particularly the Prime Minister, took a leading role creates enormous opportunities for Australian exporters into the Asia-Pacific region. An effective clean food marketing campaign could be the means for many food exporters in Australia to grasp these opportunities.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister representing the Attorney-General. There have been responsible expressions of concern that the government's racial hatred legislation is too broad in its application. Has the government got in mind any mechanism to ensure that the legislation, if passed, will work so as to avoid an unfair impact in the community?

—I thank Senator Cooney for this very timely question. We are, of course, aware of suggestions that the terms of our legislation are too broad, particularly the suggestions that the legislation goes further than those provisions in respect of racial hatred contained in the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Act. I welcome this opportunity Senator Cooney has given me to allay those concerns. There are, indeed, differences between our legislation and the New South Wales legislation. But, of course, we believe ours is better because it reflects some experiences in other jurisdictions within Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth bill is, in fact, a much better embodiment of the basic principles of criminal responsibility. For instance, it specifically requires intention to incite racial hatred. It also requires that there be reasonable likelihood of racial hatred being incited before a person can incur criminal liability. As well as that, the New South Wales act uses the term `serious contempt and severe ridicule of', which arguably extends the application of the offence to a much wider set of circumstances than the racial hatred addressed by section 60 of the Commonwealth bill.

That, of course, is not to say that the New South Wales legislation restricts free speech. It is worth referring to the comments of former Liberal senator and President of the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Board, Chris Puplick, who has said on a number of occasions that he does not believe that either the Commonwealth legislation or the New South Wales legislation restrict free speech.

He has also quite recently confirmed that the New South Wales laws are more broad ranging than those proposed by the federal government. I think we should also look to the experience reflected by Mr Puplick when he says that, five years on, racial vilification laws have made New South Wales a better place to live, providing a sound basis for education campaigns, helping to change workplace and institutional attitudes and offering numerous individuals the opportunity to take action against racist behaviour.

Senator Cooney is right: there is a need for the government to put to rest the misinformation that is being put out in the community in respect of the government's legislation. It is vitally important, I believe, that all Australians understand the details of our bill and the fact that it protects free speech while closing a gap in the legal protection available to victims of extreme racial behaviour. In that respect, I will be writing in my capacity as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to all ethnic communities, bringing to their attention the detail of the bill and also bringing to their attention the misinformation that has been perpetrated on the community.

In that context, it is worth noting the comment of Mr Mark Leibler the other day when he said, `Despite all this misinformation, the fact is that the heads of ethnic communities are not stupid, they have seen through the tactic.' The tactic they have seen through is the tactic of members of the opposition, the tactic that Mr Costello refers to as `narrowcasting'—narrowcasting being giving one message to ethnic communities, that they support the principle, and one message to the rural constituency, that they do not. As Mr Leibler would say, the heads of ethnic communities are not stupid. They can see through the fact that the opposition probably has no way of getting a bill into the parliament. It has not drafted anything; it has not given us a time frame for legislation. The only strategy it has is that strategy of narrowcasting.

The bottom line, and it is objectionable in the context of free speech, is that not only have ethnic leaders been misled and verballed but also they have been threatened in a very childish way by the opposition. That is not what we on this side of the parliament refer to as free speech. Healthy interaction is important, particularly on this issue. We want to see Senator Vanstone's bill but we do not believe we will ever get it, nor do those ethnic leaders, because as one leader, Mr Nino Randazzo, said yesterday, `The opposition's behaviour is typical of a person who has no contact whatsoever with ethnic communities. Mr Downer is a man who has never consulted with ethnic communities and will never understand the real meaning of multicultural Australia'. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to recently reported statements by Sir Julius Chan that BRA leaders and the president of the Bougainville interim government would be `hunted down and brought to bear justice', and reports that the situation in Bougainville has deteriorated to such an extent that the BRA and the BIG are now apparently under threat from what appears to be a mercenary group which includes two Australians. I ask: can the minister provide an update on the current situation in Bougainville, particularly in the light of these reports? Can he comment on any actions the Australian government can take with respect to the two Australian mercenaries who are reported to be involved?

—As to the general situation, it is of course a matter of regret to all of us that the recent Bougainville peace conference did not achieve the permanent and lasting settlement of the conflict that we had been hoping for. That may, in any event, I suppose, have been expecting too much from such an occasion after five years of conflict.

PARA.TAB: The decision by the leadership of the hard-core BRA not to attend the peace conference, for all its unfortunate character, did not prevent over a thousand other Bougainvillians from all parts of the island assembling in Arawa under the protection of the South Pacific peacekeeping force and openly sharing their views and aspirations about the situation on the island in a manner which simply has not been possible for years and which has, I think, given a new fillip and momentum to the peace process.That process has continued since the formal closure of the conference on 14 October in informal discussions which have taken place between the PNG government and various Bougainvillian groups and among Bougainvillian groups themselves. Importantly, the cease-fire has not been broken since the closure of the peace conference.

There is to be a meeting held, we understand, in Port Moresby next week between the PNG government and 20 Bougainvillean leaders, including some BRA leaders. We have been asked, as a government, to contribute to the cost of holding that meeting and we are prepared to do so.

As to Sir Julius Chan's specific comment that Senator Margetts referred to, he did say something to the effect that the BRA leadership who failed to participate would be hunted down, but in subsequent amplification of that comment he has made it clear that this did not imply any extra-legal activity on the part of the authorities but rather simply that the laws of Papua New Guinea would be applied to those who transgressed them.

As to the other point made by Senator Margetts about mercenaries and so on, we have got no information which would confirm allegations of a mercenary group operating on Bougainville to attack BRA figures. I would comment that all sorts of allegations have been made to try to shift the blame and win sympathy for the BRA, and I think some of these need to be taken with more than just a grain or two of salt.

My understanding is that it would be extremely difficult for any group which was not intimately familiar with the Bougainville terrain and which had no sophisticated logistic support to operate successfully in the way that has been alleged. In the event that Australian citizens were proven to be operating abroad in some mercenary capacity, the provisions of the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act would certainly apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister and I do acknowledge that a growing number of people on Bougainville support a peaceful resolution to the long years of conflict, but could Australia's current support of the Papua New Guinea government be seen as an endorsement of the Papua New Guinea Defence Force's final push to forcibly eliminate all opposition on Bougainville? Does the minister agree that any forceful resolution of the issue is not sustainable?

—We have argued from the outset that a forcible solution is not likely to be anything like as successful or certainly as satisfactory as a process of peaceful reconciliation through negotiation. That has been our position which we have strongly maintained all the way through. Senator Margetts talks about the PNGDF's final push to forcibly eliminate the BRA. I have just said that the cease-fire has not been broken, to our knowledge, and there is no such final push to forcibly eliminate the PNGDF. The Papua New Guinea government has been trying in recent weeks since the collapse, since the end of the peace conference—`collapse' is, I think, the wrong word—to try to develop a momentum for peace through working with those groups and individuals who have demonstrated a willingness to find a peaceful solution. If that can create a situation where more and more pressure is building up on the remnants of the BRA leadership and rebels to in fact peacefully succumb to this process and involve themselves in it, that is an infinitely better outcome than doing it more forcibly. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer him to figures released by the General Administration of Customs in China showing that in the first eight months of this year, Australia's imports into China have risen in value from $US1.2 billion last year to $US1.5 billion this year. I ask the minister whether these figures are indicative of the growth of exports of Australian goods into the Asia-Pacific region.

—I thank Senator Devereux for his question and for his and Senator Jones's continuing interest in this area. They have both raised such matters with me on several occasions. China is Australia's fastest growing regional market. One of the obvious reasons for that is the way its economy is growing so rapidly. But there is another—and from an Australian point of view more important—reason, which is our growing capacity to meet a broader range of China's needs, particularly in the area of complex manufactures. We continue to supply to China our traditional strengths in agricultural and mineral commodities, but we are adding to it a significant manufacturing export component.

PARA.TAB: The growth in exports to China is both absolute and relative.

At $A1.8 billion, as Senator Devereux said, that is 25 per cent higher than for the same period last year. That is what our figures show and it is similar to what is reflected in the Chinese data which Senator Devereux just referred to. It is especially significant because China's imports overall increased by only 15 per cent over the same period. Our growth was 25 per cent; growth overall was only 15 per cent. So it is growing rapidly in a way that is very positive but is also growing significantly as a proportion.

We do have a strong base in our exports to China, in our agricultural commodities and industrial raw materials. But what is significant in terms of jobs for Australians is the extent to which exports in manufactures are expanding. Australia's exports of complex manufactures to China have increased from $82 million in 1990 to $424 million in 1993—another $340 million worth of exports and a lot of jobs for Australians in factories and offices all around the country producing products for sale to China.

The opportunities are proliferating. The East Asia Analytical Unit of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has just put out a report entitled Tapping into China's transport infrastructure market, which has found that China expects to invest $233 billion in total infrastructure improvements between now and the end of the decade. This is an area into which Australian companies are moving more and more effectively—not just the construction companies but the design companies and the suppliers of goods and services to the infrastructure market, particularly, for example, in the communications area. So there are enormous opportunities in this rapidly growing market.

This is where APEC and the related question of negotiations for accession to GATT for China come in. It is about the government working in the region to open up more opportunities for Australians in areas where there is significant growth and where significant production possibilities and market possibilities exist.

The government cannot ensure that the private sector succeeds in winning these opportunities. We can only make it possible. APEC is a significant contribution to our capacity to do that, particularly in China but in the other 16 member countries of APEC as well, as is the negotiation over GATT accession. They are both significant boosts to our efforts to remove barriers to Australian exports and investment in the region. We hope that the Australian private sector will take up the opportunities of this positive environment that is being created, and I am confident that it will.

PARA.TAB: My concern with the development has always been the possible impact on the World Heritage values of the Hinchinbrook Channel, including the impact on seagrass beds. That is why my department commissioned a report by Mr Peter Valentine. The World Heritage nomination for the Great Barrier Reef prepared in 1980 specifically refers to the importance of seagrasses. It recognises that they are an important food source for grazing animals such as fish, turtles and dugong.

The Valentine report identified possible impacts from the Oyster Point development on seagrass beds as an issue of major concern. In particular, the report raised significant concerns about the impact of mangrove clearing on turbidity levels in the channel which `could further compromise the survival of seagrass beds and associated fauna'. Valentine recognised, however, that there was insufficient environmental information to pass judgment on the likelihood and extent of possible negative impacts on World Heritage values. This included a lack of information about the distribution and abundance of seagrasses in the vicinity of the project.

Valentine recommended that a series of baseline studies of the area should be undertaken as a prerequisite to future action. The baseline study on the distribution of seagrasses at Oyster Point done by the Queensland Department of Primary Industries has filled some critical information gaps. The complete report, as I have said, was made available to my department on 14 November; an incomplete copy was faxed on 9 November.

The DPI report confirms the presence of extensive seagrass beds, including the relatively rare species, halophila tricostata, which it says is a rare, little-studied species which should be protected. According to the report, the seagrass beds contribute a significant resource to the Hinchinbrook Channel. It points out that almost all seagrasses between Cairns and Townsville occur in areas which are `under some threat'. It recognises that the level of water turbidity can have a major impact on the survival of seagrasses. Importantly, the DPI report concludes as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Near-shore seagrass habitats, such as those at Oyster Point and adjacent to Cardwell, are important to marine ecology, to dugong and turtle populations and to the commercial prawn fishery. These habitats are only a small part of the total coastal zone and any losses need to be avoided.

The effect of this report was therefore to increase the need for an extremely cautious approach in respect of any activity which may affect the seagrass beds. The information in the DPI report reinforced Valentine's concerns about the impact of mangrove clearing and made my department look very closely at his recommendation that the proposal be further reviewed in an attempt to reduce mangrove losses.

PARA.TAB: Subsequent to receiving this report, my department was provided with other scientific assessments which indicated that the clearing of strand mangroves was likely to cause significant turbidity and therefore have a significant adverse impact on the seagrass beds. My department also became concerned about the manner in which the mangroves were being removed.

It was the combined effect of these accumulating scientific assessments, including, importantly, the DPI report and concern about the manner of clearance, that led my department to recommend that action be taken to halt the mangrove clearance. I should point out also that I am continuing to receive many representations from marine scientists who are extremely concerned about likely impacts on the channel. Those representations include the letter that Senator Reynolds has referred to. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! Senator Crowley, please continue. You have only five minutes, so direct your remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will, but Senator Tierney just said that I was perpetuating the Prime Minister's lie. I think that is most unparliamentary.
—I did not hear the comment. Senator Tierney, if you used that word, I ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw.

—I simply wanted to make the point that, if Senator Tierney wants to quote from the ABS, he should quote both figures. He should be honest in his understanding of what the 10 per cent figure refers to. If Senator Tierney had asked me the question, I would have answered that both figures are correct. To suggest, as the opposition has, that 10 per cent of families have both people unemployed is incorrect.
—Out of work.

—That is also incorrect because many of those families counted are age pensioners and are not looking for work. The figure also includes families that include students who clearly are not looking for work; parents who have a disability, which means they cannot work; families where one parent is unemployed; and families where people are retired. It includes families where at least one person is not looking for work and, in many cases, where two are not looking for work. To call them, as Senator Tierney has been doing, families where two people are unemployed is incorrect. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures also give the counter figure and say that both parents are unemployed in only 1.3 per cent of families. If Senator Tierney is going to cite the ABS, he should cite it comprehensively on both sides of the argument.

PARA.TAB: I will finish by saying that in question time today the question from one senator to another—while it is perfectly possibly under standing orders—would seem to suggest that Senator Tierney and the opposition are suffering from what they ascribe to the unemployed: loss of morale, a feeling of hopelessness, and loss of drive and self-esteem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Someone has had to write your lines for you. Isn't that cute!

—Senator Knowles's comment is very interesting but this comment is not written; it is exactly what is the case. Those opposite, as indicated by this kind of program, instead of wanting to reveal the truth of the ABS statistics, preferred to play ping-pong on the back bench over there. If they really want to know what the government is doing and how we can help people they need to get this data right because the response to families, under our white paper, is different depending on the accuracy of that claim. Senator Tierney was misrepresenting those figures and it is important that I should make it clear that what he ascribes to the Prime Minister—that is, untruth—is incorrect. The ABS data he selectively quoted from bears out what I am saying. Senator Tierney should quote it comprehensively, not selectively, or he will be perpetuating the lying myth.
—You say you weren't reading. What is that in your hand?
—What I have is the letter published in the Sydney Morning Herald today from me stating those facts.
—Senator Crowley, I ask you to withdraw the reference to lying.
—If there is any insinuation that the lying refers to the opposition, I withdraw.
—There was to me, I would have thought. The minister should withdraw that comment.
—The minister has withdrawn.

—I also ask that the minister, before she scurries out the door, table the document from which she was reading. I also ask the minister to stay and listen to the response and not creep off in a cowardly way.
—Senator Tierney, you know that that is unparliamentary. I have already spoken to you this morning about unparliamentary words. Senator Tierney, you will withdraw that comment unreservedly.
—I withdraw.

—I am going out to prepare for an estimates hearing. I do not believe that I scurry at all; it is not my style of leaving. Secondly, I am not prepared to table the document. It is a copy of the letter that I have had published in the Sydney Morning Herald today. It has been scrawled all over, and I will keep my own copy. If Senator Tierney wants what the copy says, he should read the letters in today's Sydney Morning Herald.

—It is a pity that the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) is leaving because she is trying to perpetuate the story that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was trying to put around to play down the extent of unemployment in this country. The lie to that was revealed in the weekend papers by Alan Ramsey, who took the Prime Minister apart on that matter and revealed that what Mr Fischer was saying in the other place last week was absolutely correct. Before the minister goes, I say to her that one of her own ministers, Minister Crean, also confirmed on 15 November that the 10 per cent figure is quite correct. The underlying point is that there are so many people in families in this country who cannot get work. In 1.1 million of the 4.7 million families of this nation no family member is working.

PARA.TAB: Regardless of the reason why that is the case, we have a situation where, under proper economic policies—if this government had developed proper economic policies over the last 12 years—great numbers of people from those 1.1 million families would be working. Even though the official rate for unemployment is coming down—a lot of that is because of declining participation rates and the fact that the government is defining people out of the work force by, for example, introducing the mature age allowance—huge numbers of people who are working for two, three, four, or five hours a day would love to work full time. Why do these people not work full time? Because the economic policies of this government have demolished so much work in this country and have not been able to replace it with new industries. The micro-economic reform agenda of this country that would have created the jobs these people desperately need has not been created by this government's policies, and that is to its eternal shame.

I am not surprised that we had so many interjections from the other side because this is embarrassing. We resorted to this device because we cannot get the truth out of this government. The Prime Minister's answer took only a glancing blow at truth. The fact is that, as revealed by Ramsey and as revealed by one of the government's own ministers, one out of 10 families have no work, and it is to this government's eternal shame.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is a great shame that the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) quite clearly still does not understand the problem. She has been talking about this drug being used purely and simply for the treatment of post-menopausal women with osteoporosis. I am talking about, as Senator Newman and Senator Herron have previously talked about, the treatment of osteoporosis in men. PARA.TAB: There is no point in saying that the only answer for men is to become post-menopausal. Frankly, I suggest that some probably are from time to time! But that is not the point. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to indicate my traditional opposition to the type of motion that we are confronted with every time a year is coming to its end, or a series of sittings of this kind is coming to an end. I know there has been a considerable blow-out in the time that has been utilised by the Senate in respect of a number of pieces of legislation. That included, of course, the land fund legislation, which occupied the time of this chamber to the extent of nearly 28 hours—quite a considerable period. As is the case with much of the legislation that is considered by this chamber, that was very vital legislation. I understand the government's problem. Nevertheless, I believe there is a need to reflect upon not only the damage that is done to the health of individual senators by sitting late and constantly, as is proposed by this motion, but also the effect that that has on the mature consideration of legislation that comes before this chamber.

PARA.TAB: I do not know about other senators but, after getting here at half past six or 7 o'clock in the morning and working right through until 10.30 p.m. and the adjournment debate, I get to the point where I cannot focus on the details of the legislation, and that is a problem. It is certainly a problem for me, because I have to focus on each and every piece of legislation that comes into the chamber. I do not have the advantage of being in a party where general policy decisions are made and then a spokesperson is trusted to look after those matters. From then on, party members do not need to have much of an input or give much consideration to the legislation. I acknowledge also that honourable senators have committee work to be done, which is time consuming.

I think this applies to all senators, not only to me. As far as possible, motions for extension of time should be avoided. By the time we knock off for Christmas, we will be pretty frazzled. One wonders what effect that will have on the legislation that goes through the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The opposition has not opposed the motion for an extension of time, but I want to tell the Senate how very disappointed we were that such a motion became necessary this year. With the new structure of starting earlier in the year and having three sitting periods, we believed that this would not happen and would not be necessary. It certainly comes as a considerable inconvenience to a lot of people to find that this is the case.

PARA.TAB: We believed, perhaps foolishly, that the government was planing a new approach to legislation and that the legislation would be fitted into the times that we were presented with earlier in the year. At the beginning of the session, very little work was scheduled on the program—there was very little to be done. It is all very well for senators to talk about how few bills were passed. Very few bills were put before the Senate and other matters were dealt with.

On a number of occasions, we gave up MPIs and general business. This was done earlier in the session than would normally happen to keep the program running up-to-date. We are now faced with the alternative of sitting for an extra week or putting in the time in the two weeks that this motion refers to.

As I said, we are not opposing the motion. We have cooperated with the government in working out a program. I recognise that the government has removed 18 bills from the program. The fact that the government needed to remove 18 bills to allow the balance of the program to be met within the two-week period only exacerbates the point: the program was in disorder. We are extremely disappointed at what has occurred again this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Auditor-General's report No. 7 of 1994-95 relates to an important matter of principle. The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 9 of 1994-95—Project Audit—Is Australia ready to respond to a major oil spill?—Australian Maritime Safety Authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Auditor-General's report No. 9 of 1994-95 is a very serious report. I regret that time pressures limit the things that should be said about this report. I hope that the matter will be dealt with at another time, perhaps at some greater length. For the moment, I will deal briefly with the potential for disasters and inadequate responses available that the Auditor-General finds exist as a result of the carriage of large volumes of oil around Australia. The Auditor-General says:

The potential for large economic and environmental loss from a major oil spill in Australia's marine environment is significant. The consequences of a major spill were clearly illustrated by the Exxon Valdez incident in Alaska in 1989 when 36 000 tonnes were spilled. The Australian public's attention was drawn to the Kirki incident off the coast of Western Australia in 1991 when the tanker's bow fell off. A total of 17 900 tonnes of oil spilt into the sea during the incident.
The Auditor-General points out:

More than 22 million tonnes of oil is shipped in Australian waters each year as tanker cargo. All forms of shipping make over 26 000 port visits each year. Many ships pass through or near delicate marine environments such as the Great Barrier Reef.
I briefly outline that because the Auditor-General asserts, and I understand with some strong support, that the technology currently available is such that:

. . . there is no certainty that a major oil spill can be dispersed before it impacts on the shoreline . . . the ANAO believes that there is scope for improving oil spill response arrangements and the assessment of equipment requirements.
It believes also that AMSA—
that is, the organisation responsible for trying to do something about these problems—
should encourage the States, Northern Territory and industry to assume greater responsibility for response operations, equipment storage and personnel training.
According to the Auditor-General, as the technology does not exist to prevent major oil slicks washing ashore in adverse weather the fact is:

The best that can typically be expected after a major spill is to recover 10% of the oil. The rest may well pollute the shoreline. In Australia, the Commonwealth, States, Northern Territory and industry combine their efforts through the National Plan to Combat Pollution of the Sea by Oil.

But this plan is clearly enormously inadequate and, in fact, the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure report on disaster management in June of this year said that, while the AMSA is well skilled in operational maritime matters, it needs assistance to develop and maintain the plan and integrate industry research with the plan.

PARA.TAB: According to the Auditor-General, serious weaknesses exist which should be addressed. These are briefly: there are no quantifiable targets to use as the basis of decisions about the location and amount of equipment required to combat a spill; there is a lack of designated offshore storage containers in local equipment stockpiles for use in transporting recovered oil; there are lower levels of response equipment than is required in some high risk areas in northern Australia, particularly chemical dispersant; the national plan response arrangements have not been adequately tested in scenario planning at major disaster level; and there is no representation of the salvage industry, coastal local government councils, and commercial, recreational and environmental groups on the National Plan Advisory Committee.

This is a very serious Auditor-General's report. There is much more of moment in this report that should be referred to the Senate but, in view of time pressures, I will leave it at that. I think Senator Margetts wishes to make some remarks on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to back up the remarks of Senator Michael Baume on this particular matter. One would have to say that, as we have not been able to adequately test the response arrangements for major disasters, it is more by good luck than good management in some respects that both the Kirki and the Sanko Harvest were lesser disasters than it was felt they could have been by a number of coastal communities in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume mentioned the weaknesses that have been pointed out in this audit report, and I would like to speak briefly about some of these and how they relate to Western Australia and other parts of Australia. First of all, there are no quantifiable targets to use as the basis of decisions about the location and amount of equipment required to combat a spill. That means simply that it should be possible for AMSA to say, `Our target is, within one day or two days, to have all of the equipment that might be necessary to deal with a major spill at whichever coastal location is closest to the major spill or most able to be serviced.'

The problem is that we have a huge coastline and not all of it is accessible easily by aircraft. Therefore, we may have to factor into that a fair amount of road travel. That is very important when we are talking about adequate responses. If at no stage do we have a target set, the ability of different communities to work in with a plan to make sure that their area can cope with a major spill for their particular circumstances is going to be reduced.

There is a lack of designated offshore storage containers of local equipment stockpiles. Whilst there are a number of points throughout Australia which have major stockpiles that can be brought into use, it is necessary, I believe, to have start-off equipment, that is, equipment that we can use as a first-aid measure for oil spills. If we do not have those adequately covered throughout Australia offshore then our ability to deal in the first instance is going to be very much reduced, obviously.

We have lower levels of response equipment than is required in some high risk areas in northern Australia, particularly chemical dispersants. We are dealing with areas where we might, as Senator Baume mentioned, be threatening an entire reef ecosystem, and it could also include an entire breeding area for major industries such as the prawning industry and the fishing industry.

If we do not have the levels of response equipment that is required in those kinds of areas and those kinds of circumstances, our ability to respond in any case is going to be minimised. As I said, the fact that we have not had a major disaster in a way is good but it also means that we have had no means of finding out whether our responses work. This requires coordination.

The last point is that because there is no representation of the salvage industry, many people have felt that the salvage companies have not had a lot of power of decision making in these kinds of crises. So when these tugs attach themselves to these ships, then their ability to know what the plan is and what action should be taken is limited if there has not been cooperation with the salvage companies in putting together these kinds of plans.

What we have also found in Western Australia is that local governments, certainly, but also local communities that have felt deeply the possible threat of the Kirki and the Sanko Harvest have got together quite a lot of local information about wind dispersal, tidal dispersal, their local ecosystem, and the possible impacts such a spill would have on their local economy.

Unless we can utilise that kind of good quality local information that has been built up over the years, then we are not making the best use of the possible resources that are available to deal with these kinds of issues. There are a number of recommendations that come from these. In fact, there are seven. The audit office has recommended that AMSA define its role as manager of the national plan. That does not mean that it does it all. It often means that the states take a greater role. It simply means that there is a coordinating body to make sure that all those things fit into place and everybody knows what role it plays. It does not mean the federal body taking over the role of the states. It just means making sure that someone does it and perhaps the people who are best able to do it have that role.

It is recommended that AMSA consider adopting a more strategic leadership role overseeing the states and Northern Territory, as I mentioned. It is recommended that it review the risks associated with the possible introduction of very large tankers. I think that risk also obviously has to include the type of shipping and the standard of shipping that we are getting. It is recommended that it clarify current planning assumptions regarding the design spill size and establish a benchmark of the national planned capability; that it quantify oil spill response planning standards, define equipment requirements to meet these standards and re-examine the distribution. If it provides these standards, then people know what they can expect. It also might know if things are going wrong, if things happen within a certain time.

It is recommended that it should consider a regional alliance between Australia and its northern neighbours covering oil spill prevention and response matters, thus improving protection to northern Australia—that only seems sensible—and consider establishing a national response team of specially trained operators available on request to respond quickly and expertly, regardless of jurisdictional boundaries. It seems reasonable. We are not going to have those people having a full time job all around Australia, but if we had a response team that can be called in at particular times of crisis, then it would obviously be very helpful.

People have heard me talk on a number of occasions about the concept and the problems of oil pollution. I want to tie this in with the fact that the term of reference for this inquiry was obviously to look at the ability to cope with a major oil spill. But perhaps more important than that is our ability to prevent such things. When we see things like the AMSA report, which tells us that that body has fewer staff and is having to deal with more ships, we realise that the ability to deal with and properly examine those ships is reduced. Because AMSA is dealing with more ships, its productivity might seem to be going up; but its ability to more properly deal with ships that might possibly be at risk is limited by staffing and resourcing arrangements. It is then that this kind of inadequacy becomes more and more important.

It is also important, I believe, to fully state that the possible liability should not be borne only by the environment and the communities affected. Obviously, the shipping companies have a great liability, but it is not just theirs, either. Those individuals and sectors in our community which wish to benefit from the cheaper rates of substandard and flag of convenience shipping must, in my opinion, also share some of the liability if such an accident takes place because of substandard shipping, training or staffing levels.

It is my opinion that, unless we deal with the liability regime in relation to the shipping industry in general and the oil industry in particular in Australia, we will have an even greater dependence on the kind of response we get. Of course, responses should be only the last resort. We should be making sure that we have less and less risk that these things will ever happen. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Neal and on behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present a report received by the committee from the former Comptroller-General of Customs, in relation to recommendation No. 91 of the committee's report No. 325, concerning the Midford Paramount case and related matters. The document read as follows—
Mr President, I rise today to table a report prepared for the committee by the former Comptroller-General of Customs, Mr Frank Kelly.

SPEECH.PARA: In tabling Mr Kelly's report I should make it clear that the committee stands by the principal finding in Report 325 that there were serious deficiencies in the management and operation of the Australian Customs Service at the time of the Midford Paramount case. These deficiencies were also noted in the report of the Conroy review of the Customs Service.

Mr Kelly's report has been prepared in response to recommendation 91 in the committee's Report No. 325, which was entitled The Midford Paramount Case and Related Matters. This recommendation called on the Comptroller-General to:

review the levels, functions and suitability of the Australian Customs Service officers involved in the Midford case, together with the lines of responsibility and supervision, that were clearly inadequate according to the evidence before the committee.
Mr Kelly's report was provided to the committee on 14 June 1994, under the cover of a letter from Mr Kelly's successor as Comptroller-General, Mr Lionel Woodward.

The overall finding in Mr Kelly's report is that although the performance of a number of Customs officers involved in the Midford case was flawed, `there is no evidence to support a case of fraud, dishonesty or illegal behaviour by any officer, and no basis has been found for the laying of any criminal charges' (I refer here to paragraph 153 of Mr Kelly's report).

Furthermore, Mr Kelly concludes that `in no case have I considered it to be appropriate that disciplinary action should be taken against any officer still in the Service' (I refer here to paragraph 155 of Mr Kelly's report).
Mr President, the committee has thought long and hard about whether or not to table Mr Kelly's report.
In considering the matter we have met with Mr Woodward and sought and considered the views of all of the 15 people named in Mr Kelly's report.
Although there are arguments to the contrary, the committee has decided to the table the report in its entirety.
The committee has come to this decision for two reasons.
First, because the inquiry which began this matter, the committee's inquiry into the Midford Paramount case, was a public inquiry.

Secondly, because of the strong representations made to us by most of the individuals named in the report, who believe that the tabling of the report provides them with an opportunity to clear their names.

Another relevant consideration was advice the committee received from Mr Woodward that, on the basis of the information he has considered about the Midford case and the roles of the respective officers, he will not be taking any prosecution or disciplinary action against any officer named in Mr Kelly's report.

I know that the Midford case and the subsequent reviews have been a difficult and unpleasant experience for some staff within the Customs Service. To these people I say, on behalf of the committee, that I note both Mr Kelly's conclusions and Mr Woodward's advice.

I have been pleased to see that since the tabling of the committee's report and the release of the Conroy Review, significant steps have been taken to improve management, accountability and reporting systems within Customs. There are clear signs that lessons are being learned from the mistakes of the past.
It is the committee's hope that the tabling of Mr Kelly's report will represent the final chapter in the Midford saga.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have a speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee's thirteenth report of 1994 deals with the proposed upgrading of accommodation at HMAS Watson, NSW.

HMAS Watson, located on Sydney Harbour, is a major Naval training establishment which carries out specialist warfare and navigation training for naval personnel. Most of the buildings were built in the 1950s.

The proposal examined by the committee involves the provision of new or upgraded living-in accommodation for 346 Service personnel, additional office space and classrooms, improved recreation facilities and additional parking space.
The committee has recommended that the proposal should proceed at an estimated out-turn cost of $18.81 million.

After having inspected existing facilities at the base the committee was convinced that if HMAS Watson is to remain as a major training establishment for the Navy, the standard of accommodation available for personnel must be improved, and shortfalls in the amount of accommodation available must be rectified. This applies to recreation and dining facilities as well, especially for junior and senior sailors.
The committee noted that some investment in training facilities has been made at HMAS Watson in recent years and saw two excellent new training facilities during the inspection of the base.

Nevertheless a number of other essential training facilities are spread out, lack adequate space and should be upgraded or replaced to enable HMAS Watson to continue its role as a major naval training establishment.

During the inspection of the base the committee saw that the boundary of the Sydney Harbour National Park, which surrounds the base on three sides, has considerable exotic vegetation which Defence has offered to restore to more natural bushland. The committee has recommended that Defence should press the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service to accept the Defence offer to assist with the restoration of bushland in areas near the Sydney Harbour National Park boundary, which is currently in a poor state, adjacent to HMAS Watson.

At the public hearing a number of community groups expressed concern about the master planning of the base and the apparent visual intrusiveness of a number of new buildings which will be constructed. The committee has taken these concerns on board and has recommended:
First, a consultative committee should be established to provide a forum for the exchange of views on planning and management matters affecting HMAS Watson and the local community.

Secondly, that a number adjustments to various layouts and designs should be made, including the distance of the proposed junior officers' accommodation from the Sydney Harbour National Park boundary.

Thirdly, the committee has suggested that for future projects, baseline planning documents such as master plans should be prepared well in advance of proposals being referred to the committee. This will enable local planning authorities and community groups to provide comment and to be advised of general planning objectives well before specific work takes place.

In conclusion, the overall scope of the upgrading of HMAS Watson will be adequate to cater for known future requirements as Defence does not believe it will be necessary to undertake further development work at HMAS Watson for some time.
I commend the report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about Telecom, about accountability and about the unwarranted rejection of yet another Australian small business in favour of a foreign supplier. RF Devices is an Australian manufacturer of microcells—a device to site a mobile telephone system at a distance from the transmitter using fibre optic technology. The RF Devices product is called `Lightcell'. RF Devices has a good track record of competent product delivery. RF Devices has been trying to sell its product to Telecom.

PARA.TAB: The only competitor product for Lightcell is an American product. My information is that Lightcell offers Australia a range of advantages over the American product, and they are: technical superiority; significantly cheaper—of the order of 40 per cent; better local technical support; local stocks of replacement parts; and a longer warranty. Normally, one would think that would be enough to win a tender. But, in addition, Lightcell is designed and made in Australia; it provides local employment; it replaces imports; and it is a product with export potential.

The government and Telecom both claim to have a policy of supporting Australian industry development through their purchasing policies. Nevertheless, in June this year, RF Devices approached me and told me that it had information that, no matter how much better its product was, Telecom would buy from the Americans because of the views of a particular Telecom purchasing officer. RF Devices felt that, even if it offered its product for free, Telecom would still buy from the Americans. I am sad to say that events appeared to have proved RF Devices right.

We took the matter up with the Minister for Communications, Mr Lee, and asked him to intervene. We asked him to ask the identified purchasing officer to stand aside just for this one tender—not because we had convicted him without a trial, as people might claim, but because it is important that purchasing by government business enterprises is not only fair, but is also seen to be fair.

The minister told us that he cannot intervene in the commercial operations of Telecom. Just think about that, Madam Acting Deputy President. The Australian taxpayer is the 100 per cent owner of Telecom, but does not have any say in ensuring that Telecom operates in a fair and proper manner in expending taxpayer money.

We also asked if we could, in confidence, have a look at tender assessment documentation. Again, we were told this could not to be done. Apparently, there is no way to hold Telecom accountable for how it spends government money. The minister passed on our concerns to Telecom, and I acknowledge that gratefully. Essentially, however, we have been told that Telecom was asked whether it was going to be fair and Telecom replied that it would be. That is the extent to which the public can get assurance: Telecom telling us it is being fair. So we, I guess, have to believe it.

RF Devices, despite its misgivings about whether it would get a fair go, went to the time, trouble and expense of preparing an excellent tender for Telecom's latest requirement for 50 units of the microcell product. This week it was told by Telecom that its tender was by far the lowest priced tender. Telecom has not told RF Devices of any deficiencies in its product. However, Telecom offered RF Devices only five of the 50 units—10 per cent of the available order. The remaining 45 units were to go to the more expensive and—it is claimed—technically inferior American product. No reason, however, was given. Five units is not a sufficient order to be economic. We suspect that it is a sop to keep RF Devices quiet. Telecom also vaguely spoke about developing future business. Another sop. It is known that this is the last tender for this type of product that Telecom will be putting out.

This is a matter of great concern. Here we have a government and business enterprises—both government and private—saying that we must create employment in Australia, that we must buy Australian and that we must support local industries. Yet here we have a government business enterprise giving preference to

SPEECH.PARA: a foreign company, when all the evidence appears to suggest that the Australian company should have got the order. I expect, having put this on the public record, that either we will see a change in the attitude of Telecom and a reversal of the procedure it has adopted and the way in which it has placed this order—even on this particular order—or we will get an explanation from both Telecom and the minister as to why this particular destructive course of action is being followed.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
